fdd:description.p: Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL), pronounced “smile”, is a legacy World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) open standard, extensible markup language prepared by the Synchronized Multimedia Working Group (SYMM WG). The Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL 3.0), W3C Recommendation 01 December 2008 standard is the most current version as of this writing in 2025, extending functionalities contained in SMIL 2.1, released on 13 December 2005. See SMIL for overall details about the format and other versions beyond version 2.1.

Key changes for SMIL 2.1 over SMIL 2.0 (07 January 2005) include the addition of new Mobile Profiles to support use on mobile devices: SMIL 2.1 Mobile Profile and SMIL 2.1 Extended Mobile Profile. Other updates are listed in Summary of Changes for SMIL 2.1.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL) version 2.1 was released in December 2005 as an open standard, XML-based markup language authors use to create interactive multimedia presentations. It has been superseded by version 3 released in 2008.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Per standard, "The elements names, attributes names and attribute values of SMIL linking constructs are, where possible, the same as constructs in XHTML [XHTML11] with corresponding linking behavior."

Per standard, "Allow reusing of SMIL 2.1 syntax and semantics in other XML-based languages, in particular those who need to represent timing and synchronization. For example, SMIL 2.1 components are used for integrating timing into XHTML [XHTML10] and into SVG [SVG]."

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Per standard, "SMIL 2.1 components are used for integrating timing into SVG [SVG]."
Per standard, “Any use of CSS styles and properties shall conform to Cascading Style Sheets, level 2 CSS2 Specification.”

fdd:comment.p: The TTML1 specification states “While TTML is not expressly designed for direct (embedded) integration into an HTML or a SMIL document instance, such integration is not precluded.”

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Open standard and fully documented. Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL) 2.1 is a W3C Recommendation although it has been superseded by SMIL 3.0.

fdd:documentation.p: Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL 2.1) | W3C Recommendation 13 December 2005. Maintained by W3C and the Synchronized Multimedia Working Group (SSMM WG).
See SMIL links to other versions.

fdd:adoption.p: SMIL 2.1 is now a legacy format and has been superseded by SMIL 3.0.W3C provides a SMIL 2.1 test suite and SMIL 2.1 Interoperability Implementation Report. See SMIL for discussion of SMIL adoption overall.

fdd:licensingAndPatents.p: None. The W3C Patent Policy governs the handling of patents in the process of producing Web standards. The W3C Patent Policy has the goal of assuring that all W3C Recommendations can be implemented on a royalty-free basis.

fdd:transparency.p: SMIL 2.1 files are XML-based, so they are both human-readable and machine-readable. These files are plain text, which means they can be viewed with any text editor.
While SMIL files can be written using a simple text-editor, there are authoring applications that allow users to produce SMIL presentation content.
The W3C’s Synchronized Multimedia page lists a variety of Authoring Tools, some of which are specific to SMIL 2.1.

fdd:selfDocumentation.p: The SMIL 2.1 metadata element "extends SMIL 1.0 meta information functionalities with the new metadata element to host RDF statements as RDF provides a more general treatment of metadata. RDF is a declarative language and provides a standard way for using XML to represent metadata in the form of statements about properties and relationships of items on the Web. Such items, known as resources, can be almost anything, provided it has a Web address. This means that you can associate metadata information with a SMIL document, but also a graphic, an audio file, a movie clip, and so on."

SMIL overall has excellent capacity for accessibility support. W3C's SMIL Techniques for WCAG 2.0 details providing audio description, extended audio description, captions in synchronized streams and sign language interpretation in synchronized streams for SMIL 1.0 and SMIL 2.0. There is also strong support documented in Accessibility Features of SMIL.

SMIL 2.1 specifically includes MediaAccessibility and MediaDescription modules to support alt text as well as a new accessibility attribute: readIndex, which "Allows explicit ordering for controlling assistive technology."

fdd:externalDependencies.p: None beyond availability of supporting software/hardware.
The standarddefines a SMIL document player as “those applications that support playback of “application/smil+xml” documents and host language conformant document profiles.”
The W3C’s Synchronized Multimedia page lists SMIL players that support(ed) SMIL 2.1, including Ambulant and RealPlayer version 11.

fdd:techProtection.p: RFC 4536 published May 2006 - IANA.org Regulations Security Considerations: See Section 6, "Security Considerations."

Network Working Group | Request for Comments: 4536 The application/smil and application/smil+xml Media Types, Security Considerations, Section 6: “SMIL documents contain a construct that allows "infinite loops". This is indispensable for a multimedia format. However, SMIL clients should foresee provisions such as a "stop" button that lets users interrupt such an "infinite loop". As with HTML, SMIL documents contain links to other media (images, sounds, videos, text, etc.), and those links are typically followed automatically by software, resulting in the transfer of files without the explicit request of the user for each one. The security The SMIL language contains "switch" elements. SMIL provides no mechanism that ensures that the media objects contained in a "switch" element provide equivalent information. An author knowing that one SMIL player will display one alternative of a "switch" and another will display a different part can put different information in the two parts. While there are legitimate use cases for this, it also gives rise to a security consideration: The author can fool viewers into thinking that the same information was displayed when in fact it was not. In addition, all of the security considerations of RFC 3023 also apply to SMIL.”

fdd:normalText.p: Good support. Per the standard, “SMIL 2.1 Conformant document MUST be well-formed XML.” See XML. Comments welcome.

fdd:beyondText.p: SMIL 2.1 defines profiles for mobile device use. See XML. Comments welcome.

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: Per IANA.org “NOTE: On the Windows operating system and the Macintosh platform, the ".smi" extension is used by other formats. To avoid conflicts, it is thus recommended to use the extension ".smil" for storing SMIL files on these platforms.” See https://www.iana.org/assignments/media- types/application/smil.

fdd:magicNumbers.fdd:note: RFC 4536 published May 2006 – IANA.org Regulations Magic Numbers: “There is no single initial byte sequence that is always present for SMIL files.” Section 4 of RFC 4536 document gives some guidelines for recognizing SMIL files.
